metadata.paragraph_text_preview: This is a case about alleged retaliation and censorship arising from immigration enforcement linked ...

target:
This is a case about alleged retaliation and censorship arising from immigration enforcement linked to political advocacy for Palestine. On March 15, 2025, three individuals filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of New York. They sued President Donald Trump, the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, and other federal officials under the First Amendment and Fifth Amendment. Represented by individual attorneys and attorneys from Davis, Ndanusa, Ikhlas & Saleem LLP, the American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee, and Project TAHA, the plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, along with attorneys’ fees. They claimed that two executive orders—Executive Order 14161 and Executive Order 14188—unconstitutionally chilled protected speech by threatening criminal prosecution or deportation for individuals who expressed viewpoints critical of the U.S. or Israeli governments. The plaintiffs alleged that these executive orders were being used to surveil, silence, and threaten activists with detention or deportation solely based on their political beliefs and associations.

On the same day the complaint was filed, the plaintiffs submitted a motion for a temporary restraining order to prevent enforcement of the challenged executive orders. On March 19, 2025, the Court received an ex parte version of the TRO motion. On March 20, 2025, the Court denied the ex parte request and ordered the plaintiffs to show cause by 5:00 p.m. that same day why the motion should not be placed on the public docket. The plaintiffs did not respond to the order to show cause.

A hearing on the TRO was held on March 25, 2025, and on March 27, 2025, the Court again denied the TRO. The Court concluded that the plaintiffs had failed to establish a likelihood of success on the merits or demonstrate irreparable harm. It also noted that plaintiff Momodou Taal’s visa had already been revoked, which, in the Court’s view, undermined the urgency and necessity of immediate relief. The Court's opinion emphasized that while the plaintiffs raised serious constitutional concerns, they had not met the high threshold required for emergency injunctive relief.

Also on March 27, 2025, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint, adding as defendants the acting directors of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and the Buffalo Field Office of ICE. They filed a renewed TRO motion, this time seeking to enjoin federal officials from detaining or removing Taal from the Court’s jurisdiction while the case proceeded. The plaintiffs alleged that Taal had significantly curtailed his speech and public advocacy out of fear of government reprisal under the executive orders. They also cited heightened enforcement activity, including surveillance outside Taal’s residence and direct instructions from ICE agents to report for detention.

On March 31, 2025, the plaintiffs filed a notice of voluntary dismissal without prejudice, and on April 2, 2025, the Court formally closed the case. According to the plaintiffs, they withdrew the lawsuit in light of escalating enforcement threats, including revocation of immigration status, visible surveillance, and the threat of imminent detention. No injunctive relief was granted, and the case was dismissed without any ruling on the merits.

They claimed that two executive orders—Executive Order 14161 and Executive Order 14188—unconstitutionally chilled protected speech by threatening criminal prosecution or deportation for individuals who expressed viewpoints critical of the U.S. or Israeli governments. The plaintiffs alleged that these executive orders were being used to surveil, silence, and threaten activists with detention or deportation solely based on their political beliefs and associations.

Plaintiff: Three individual activists advocating for Palestine, including Momodou Taal; Defendants: President Donald Trump (President of the United States), the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, the acting Directors of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and ICE’s Buffalo Field Office, and other unnamed federal officials.

Three plaintiffs filed a First and Fifth Amendment lawsuit on March 15, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York against President Donald Trump, DHS, and other federal officials.
Plaintiffs alleged Executive Orders 14161 and 14188 were used to surveil, silence, and threaten critics of U.S. or Israeli policy with prosecution, detention, or deportation.
Complaint filed – March 15, 2025 (U.S. District Court, N.D.N.Y.)
